description.narrative: Health facilities and communities are able to provide quality Integrated Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition (IMSAM) as per the national guidelines.

sector.narrative: Care for children with severe acute malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Health facilities and communities are able to provide quality Integrated Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition (IMSAM) as per the national guidelines.

description.narrative: Between 2015 and 2018, UNICEF has supported to increase the coverage of quality care for severely acute malnourished children from 60% to 77% and this contributing to the decrease in prevalence of severe acute malnutrition among children 0-59 months from 9.9% in 2010 to 2.7% in 2018 in South-Sudan | Status:Met | As-of Date:16/12/2018

title.narrative: % of health facilities with stock out of SAM supplies for more than one month
In humanitarian situations: Number of children aged 6-59 months with SAM who are admitted for treatment
Number of health and nutrition workers trained on management of SAM as per the national protocol
Number of Sphere standards met (in relation to the management of SAM)
Average number of health facilities that provide treatment services for management of SAM
